content:
There's a comment on the forum ( https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-simple-blur/192175/2 ) which seems to suggest that the player doesn't understand the input. I've just edited the description in Input section to make it easier to understand. I've also added "rows x cols lines" to Output section.

Original input section for reference:

A 2-dimensional grid of pixels, with each pixel defined by its red, green, and blue values.

The first line of input gives the size of the grid, in rows and columns respectively.
Each subsequent line contains a pixel's RGB values in a space-separated list. The pixels are given in left-to-right, top-to-bottom order.
Edited to improve the formatting and stub.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Overall, just great work.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Some image processing is nice. Note I find the constraints a bit confusing using X. It would be better to add variables like 0 <= [[red]], [[green]], [[blue]] <= 255
The word "rectilinear" makes the statement a bit less approachable than it could be

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Not many concerns and they are resolved.
Nice job!

I am missing an info about the data representation.
The pixels of the image are given but in which order? I supposed they are given row by row (from left to right) but they could have been given column by column with a different output.

I think you should include constraints of sizes.
Also, change 0>=X<=255 to 0<=X<=255

(And when I test it, I found out in the first case the G of the 5th grid will be 114/4, which will be 28.5, and the answer is 28, while the R of the 2nd grid will be 398/4, which is 99.5 and the answer is 100. You should specify that when meeting 0.5 the player should round it to 0 or 1.)

Thank you for your feedback! I have made the changes in constraints, and since I don't want the minutiae of different rounding protocols between languages or anything like that to be the focal point of this challenge, I've recalculated all the test answers to use flooring instead of rounding.
Thank you for your feedback! I have added a line to the input section to clarify that the input is provided left-to-right, top-to-bottom.
Thanks for the note! I have taken out this word and replaced it with the explicit list "above, below, left, and right".
